abstract: The British oil firm’s chief no longer has credibility with shareholders, regulators or consumers.
snippet: The British oil firm’s chief no longer has credibility with shareholders, regulators or consumers.
lead_paragraph: The moment has arrived for Tony Hayward to call time on his career as chief executive of BP. The British oil firm’s chief does not have the credibility with shareholders, regulators or consumers to continue in his role once the Gulf of Mexico crisis is over. BP, and Mr. Hayward’s own career prospects, will be better off if he admits this simple truth.

headline.main: A Slip too Many for BP’s Chief
headline.print_headline: A Slip Too Many For BP’s Chief

byline.original: By CHRISTOPHER HUGHES  and ANTONY CURRIE

abstract: JPMorgan Chase has made heavy losses from bad coal-price bets, traders dealing with the U.S. investment bank told Reuters, at a time when proprietary trading at deposit-taking banks faces increased regulatory scrutiny.
snippet: JPMorgan Chase has made heavy losses from bad coal-price bets, traders dealing with the U.S. investment bank told Reuters, at a time when proprietary trading at deposit-taking banks faces increased regulatory scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase has racked up heavy losses from bad coal-price bets, traders dealing with the U.S. investment bank told Reuters, at a time when proprietary trading at deposit-taking banks faces increased regulatory scrutiny.

headline.main: JPMorgan Hit by Coal-Trading Losses, Traders Say

abstract: JPMorgan said Wednesday that it would form a joint venture with First Capital Securities of China to underwrite share issues in the country.
snippet: JPMorgan said Wednesday that it would form a joint venture with First Capital Securities of China to underwrite share issues in the country.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan said Wednesday that it would form a joint venture with First Capital Securities of China to underwrite stock issues in the country.

headline.main: JPMorgan Enters Underwriting Venture in China

abstract: Thomas Lee, the chief United States equity strategist at JPMorgan Chase, thinks the next bubble could be in high-quality corporate bonds as investors burned after stocks plunged from late 2007 to early 2009 flock to perceived safety.
snippet: Thomas Lee, the chief United States equity strategist at JPMorgan Chase, thinks the next bubble could be in high-quality corporate bonds as investors burned after stocks plunged from late 2007 to early 2009 flock to perceived safety.
lead_paragraph: Tulip bulbs. Gold. The Internet. Real estate. History is littered with asset bubbles in which investors piled into the next hot thing, only to lose much or all of their investments once the bubble bursts.

headline.main: JPMorgan Strategist Sees Possible Bubble in Bonds
